title: Landmark Victory for Senior Citizens’ Rights: Bombay High Court Upholds Eviction Order Under The Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens Act, 2007
description:
The Bombay High Court has reaffirmed the rights of senior citizens under The Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens Act, 2007, in a case involving Chandiram and Sushila Hemnani, who sought the eviction of their son and daughter-in-law from their property due to a hostile living environment exacerbated by frivolous litigation.

The elderly couple, owners of a bungalow in Maharashtra, had permitted their son and daughter-in-law to reside with them, but subsequent disputes led to significant harassment. After a Tribunal initially ordered the eviction, the Senior Citizens Appellate Tribunal reversed this decision, prompting the senior citizens to file a writ petition in the High Court.

The High Court, referencing previous judgments and emphasizing the Act's intent to protect senior citizens, overturned the Appellate Tribunal's decision. The court highlighted the couple's ownership of the property and the daughter-in-law's failure to establish any legal right to reside there. The court directed the respondents to vacate the premises within 30 days and awarded costs to the petitioners. The judgment reinforces the importance of safeguarding the rights of senior citizens and ensuring their peaceful enjoyment of their property, setting a precedent for similar cases.

title: Delhi RERA 2025 Directions: A New Era of Compliance and Transparency
description:
The Delhi Real Estate Regulatory Authority (Delhi RERA) has implemented new directions under Section 37 of the Real Estate (Regulation and Development) Act, 2016, aimed at enhancing compliance among promoters and agents in Delhi. These directions address prevalent issues such as outdated project statuses and opaque financial reporting, signaling a move towards stricter regulatory enforcement.

These directions reflect Delhi RERA’s proactive approach to monitoring and enforcing compliance, highlighting the importance of developers fulfilling their regulatory duties, including timely status updates, quarterly progress reports, and adherence to proper banking protocols. They also serve as a message to homebuyers that their rights to information, accountability, and project certainty are being prioritized.

Ultimately, the Delhi RERA Directions 2025 represent a shift from passive registration to active regulatory monitoring, emphasizing transparency and accountability within the real estate sector. This initiative aims to restore buyer confidence and eliminate unscrupulous actors, placing the onus on promoters and agents to adhere to these enhanced compliance standards.

title: Supreme Court Clarifies Legal Divide Between Agreement to Sell and Registered Conveyance
description:
The Supreme Court of India, in *Vinod Infra Developers Ltd. v. Mahaveer Lunia & Ors.*, reaffirmed the legal principle that an Agreement to Sell (ATS), even with possession or payment, does not confer ownership rights to immovable property without a registered sale deed. The court emphasized that title transfer necessitates a registered conveyance and that claims based solely on unregistered ATS are unenforceable unless a suit for specific performance is filed.

The case arose from a dispute where the appellant challenged the validity of sale deeds executed based on an unregistered ATS and power of attorney, arguing they were security for a loan and subsequently revoked. Despite the revocation, the respondents registered sale deeds. The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, restoring the plaint, and asserted that revocation of the power of attorney voided the subsequent sale deeds. The Court reiterated that SA/GPA/WILL transactions do not constitute valid transfers and cannot substitute for a registered sale deed.

The Court also clarified that a plaint with multiple causes of action cannot be rejected entirely if one relief is legally untenable. Furthermore, the Court held that ownership and title disputes fall under the jurisdiction of civil courts, not revenue courts, as revenue records are for fiscal purposes and do not confer title. This decision reinforces the importance of registered conveyance deeds for legally transferring immovable property and promotes transparency in real estate transactions.

title: Misconduct Beyond Workplace: Judicial Deference in Government Contractual Employment
description:
The case of *Executive Secretary of District Health Society vs. K.S. Subha Karuthukhan* highlights the complexities of balancing employment contracts with public conduct expectations, particularly concerning the Tamil Nadu Government Servants’ Conduct Rules, 1973. The legal dispute arose after a contractual employee's disengagement following allegations of misconduct stemming from a matrimonial dispute, raising questions about employment security, the definition of misconduct under service rules, and the extent of judicial intervention in employment decisions.

The employee, initially appointed as a Dental Assistant on a contractual basis, was disengaged after being implicated in a criminal case related to a matrimonial dispute. While the writ court initially ruled in favor of the employee, arguing the personal dispute shouldn't affect his employment, the appellants contended that the employee's conduct violated the professional standards expected of public servants under the Conduct Rules, which permit disciplinary action for misconduct even outside the workplace. The respondent maintained the allegations were unrelated to his professional role and his performance was satisfactory.

The division bench overturned the writ court's decision, emphasizing that public servants are expected to uphold integrity in both professional and personal lives, and misconduct under the Conduct Rules extends beyond workplace behavior to actions that could tarnish public service. The court acknowledged the respondent's contractual term had expired, making reinstatement untenable, and stressed judicial intervention in contractual employment matters should be cautious. The final decision affirmed the government's authority to initiate disciplinary measures for conduct violations, whether professional or personal, underscoring the judiciary's role in respecting administrative autonomy while ensuring fairness. This case serves as a precedent for interpreting misconduct and contractual obligations in public administration.

title: Balancing Development and Conservation: The Mumbai Open Spaces Debate
description:
The Bombay High Court, in the case of NAGAR vs State of Maharashtra, addressed the conflict between urban development and environmental conservation in Mumbai. The case challenged the Maharashtra Government's policy allowing the use of public recreational spaces for slum rehabilitation, highlighting the need to balance housing with the preservation of open spaces.

The legal challenge stemmed from a government notification and amendments to the Development Control and Promotion Regulations (DCPR) 2034, which permitted converting open spaces into housing zones. NAGAR argued this contravened the city's Development Plan and undermined urban health by diminishing vital recreational areas. The petition invoked constitutional principles, the Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning Act, 1966 (MRTP Act), the Doctrine of Public Trust, Sustainable Development, and the Precautionary Principle.

The Bombay High Court acknowledged Mumbai's housing shortage but emphasized the importance of public open spaces for well-being. It struck down the contentious provisions of Regulation 17(3)(D)(2), deeming them inconsistent with urban planning principles and constitutional mandates, and directed the State to revise housing policies to align with the MRTP Act. The judgment serves as a precedent for balancing urban development and environmental conservation, reaffirming the importance of preserving public spaces and integrating inclusivity with sustainability.

title: NCDRC Clarifies “Consumer” Status In Real Estate Transactions: Key Takeaways From Mrs. Rajni Suryakant Gujar V. Shree Vinayaka Developers
description:
The National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (NCDRC) has reaffirmed the definition of a "consumer" under the Consumer Protection Act, particularly in real estate transactions, in the case of *Mrs. Rajni Suryakant Gujar v. Shree Vinayaka Developers*. The case involved a dispute over a property transaction where the appellants, engaged in real estate brokerage, sought to purchase a plot but were denied the sale deed despite making payments.

The NCDRC upheld the dismissal of the consumer complaint, citing the Supreme Court's precedent that purchases for commercial purposes do not qualify the purchaser as a "consumer." The commission found that the appellants' transaction was part of their regular commercial activity, thus excluding them from consumer status under both the 1986 and 2019 Consumer Protection Acts.

Furthermore, the NCDRC addressed the issue of transacting with an individual partner of the developer firm, noting that the partnership deed required transactions to be conducted in the firm's name. Given allegations of fraud and the complex nature of the dispute, the Commission directed the appellants to pursue remedies in civil or criminal courts, as consumer forums are not suited for adjudicating such matters. This decision underscores the importance of evaluating the complainant's consumer status and the capacity in which parties contract, ensuring consumer forums focus on protecting genuine consumers rather than commercial operators or investors.

title: Pharmacy Council of India (Manner of Holding Inquiry and Imposition of Penalty) Regulations, 2025 Notified
description:
The Pharmacy Council of India (PCI) has notified the "Pharmacy Council of India (Manner of Holding Inquiry and Imposition of Penalty) Regulations, 2025," effective from June 10, 2025. These regulations aim to streamline inquiry processes and penalty imposition under the Pharmacy Act, 1948, enhancing regulatory oversight and compliance within the pharmacy sector. The regulations define key terms, including "Act," "adjudicating officer," "appellant," and "appellate authority," to ensure clarity and uniformity in their application.

The regulations outline procedures for filing complaints, which can be submitted electronically, via speed post, or in person using Form-I. Upon receiving a complaint, the adjudicating officer issues a notice (Form-II) to the respondent, specifying the alleged contravention and requiring a response within a specified period. The officer then decides whether to proceed with an inquiry, providing the respondent an opportunity to present evidence (Form-III). The officer can enforce attendance of individuals relevant to the case and may proceed in absentia if the respondent fails to appear. Penalties are imposed via written order specifying reasons and the contravened provision of the Act.

An appeal process is also detailed, allowing aggrieved parties to file an appeal (Form-IV) to the appellate authority within 45 days. The appeal must include a copy of the adjudicating officer's order, a statement of facts, and grounds for the appeal. The appellate authority reviews the appeal, may request records, and must dispose of the appeal within 90 days of filing.

Orders issued under these regulations must be dated, signed, and communicated to all parties, with penalties credited to the respective state pharmacy council's account. The regulations are issued under the powers conferred by Section 18(1) and Section 18(2)(i) of the Pharmacy Act, 1948, with Central Government approval, and published in the Gazette of India. These regulations provide a comprehensive framework for ensuring accountability and transparency within the pharmacy sector, ultimately benefiting patients and healthcare providers.

title: Kerala High Court Bans Single-Use Plastics in Hilly Tourist Hotspots
description:
The Kerala High Court has initiated proceedings to address the unchecked use of single-use plastics (SUPs) in the state's ecologically fragile hilly tourist regions. Taking Suo-motu cognizance of the matter, the court reaffirmed the constitutional obligation to safeguard the environment and issued detailed directions for strict enforcement of the Environment (Protection) Act, 1986, and the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016, effective from October 2, 2025. This intervention addresses the increasing plastic pollution in high-footfall tourist destinations despite existing state bans.

The Court identified major hill stations as plastic pollution hotspots due to high tourist footfall. It imposed a complete ban on specific SUPs in these areas, exempting only larger plastic water and soft drink bottles. The ban extends to official events and private gatherings, covering items like plastic plates, cups, and straws. The court has instructed that licenses for establishments should now incorporate these restrictions.

To facilitate the transition, the court prescribed viable eco-friendly alternatives and directed the establishment of clean water kiosks and refill stations. Local authorities are tasked with regular clean-up drives of rivers, canals, and backwaters, and must collaborate with voluntary organizations. Additionally, the court emphasized the enforcement of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) obligations, mandating producers, importers, and brand owners to manage post-consumer plastic waste effectively. The Chief Secretary and the Principal Secretary of the Local Self Government Department were directed to lead the implementation.

The ruling strengthens the legal and constitutional framework for environmental protection in India, drawing upon constitutional provisions, environmental statutes, and delegated legislation. By reinforcing EPR, the Court aims to shift accountability upstream, embedding sustainability into the production and distribution cycle and promoting a circular plastic economy. The judgment provides a practical roadmap for sustainable environmental governance and sets a precedent for other states to follow.

title: No Title Without Registration: Supreme Court Clarifies Ownership Under Indian Property Law
description:
The Supreme Court of India has reaffirmed that a registered instrument is mandatory for the transfer of immovable property. In *Mahnoor Fatima Imran & Ors. v. State of Telangana & Ors.*, the Court ruled that an unregistered agreement to sell, even if validated later, does not confer legal title. The decision arose from a dispute over land in Telangana, emphasizing that mere possession, if not lawfully established, cannot justify protection from dispossession under Article 226 of the Constitution.

The case involved 53 acres of land originally part of a larger tract declared surplus under the Andhra Pradesh Land Reforms (Ceiling on Agricultural Holdings) Act, 1973. A cooperative society claimed to have purchased the land via an unregistered agreement in 1982, later "validated" in 2006. Subsequently, the society executed registered sale deeds to individuals who sought protection from dispossession, claiming unlawful takeover by the Telangana State Industrial Infrastructure Corporation (TSIIC).

The Supreme Court underscored the importance of the Registration Act, 1908, mandating registration for any document transferring rights in immovable property. The unregistered 1982 agreement, despite its "validation," remained legally ineffective. The Court also pointed to conflicting versions of the agreement, casting doubt on its authenticity. The Court reiterated that only a registered sale deed confers ownership, referencing Suraj Lamp & Industries Pvt. Ltd. v. State of Haryana. Additionally, the petitioners failed to establish lawful possession and statutory vesting of the land in the State under land reform laws further negated any claim of ownership.

This ruling has significant implications for legal practitioners, real estate stakeholders, buyers, developers, and financial institutions. It emphasizes the need for thorough due diligence, verifying documentation, legal history, and statutory status of land, ensuring every transaction is backed by a properly executed and registered sale deed. The Supreme Court ruling reinforces that registered ownership is the only valid foundation for title to immovable property, safeguarding against claims based on unregistered agreements or mere possession.

title: TikTok Denied Entry to the List of Well-Known Trademarks by Bombay High Court
description:
The Bombay High Court upheld the Registrar of TradeMarks' decision to deny TikTok's application for inclusion in the list of well-known trademarks under Rule 124 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017. This decision was based on the Government of India's ban of TikTok due to concerns over national sovereignty, data privacy, and cyber safety under the Information Technology Act, 2000.

TikTok argued that the Registrar's decision demonstrated a lack of consideration of the material presented and incorrectly invoked Section 9 of the Trade Marks Act. The court, however, found that Section 11(6) is illustrative, not exhaustive, allowing the Registrar to consider any relevant fact, including matters of public policy and constitutional values when evaluating applications for well-known status.

The Court observed that while TikTok remains a registered trademark with statutory protection, the enhanced protection conferred by "well-known mark" status was not warranted given the ongoing ban. The decision reinforces that acknowledgment of a trademark as "well-known" requires compliance with domestic legislation, public interest considerations, and constitutional protections, and is not solely determined by global popularity.

title: CCI’s Table Tennis Verdict: A New Framework for Competition Law in Indian Sports Governance
description:
The Competition Commission of India's (CCI) order in *TT Friendly Super League Association v. Table Tennis Federation of India* establishes a significant precedent for applying competition law to sports governance in India. Delivered in December 2024, the ruling clarifies that the regulatory status and non-profit nature of sports bodies do not exempt them from antitrust scrutiny when they operate as market participants. The case addresses whether a regulator can also act as a competitor, with the CCI firmly stating they cannot.

The case originated from a complaint by TT Friendly Super League Association (TTFSL), an organization running non-ranking table tennis tournaments, against a WhatsApp advisory issued by the Suburban Table Tennis Association (TSTTA). The advisory warned players against participating in unaffiliated events, threatening suspension from official tournaments. TTFSL alleged anti-competitive conduct under Sections 3 and 4 of the Competition Act, 2002. The CCI investigated the conduct of four associations, identifying relevant markets as the "market for organizing table tennis events in Maharashtra" and the "market for regulating professional table tennis in India." All four associations were deemed “enterprises” involved in economic activities.

The Commission concluded that the associations abused their dominant positions, violating Sections 4(2)(a)(i), 4(2)(b)(i), and 4(2)(c) of the Competition Act, 2002. The WhatsApp advisory was considered a coercive directive restricting player participation in independent tournaments. Clauses within the Table Tennis Federation of India's Memorandum of Association (MoA) were also found to be overly restrictive and anti-competitive. Furthermore, TSTTA's conduct constituted vertical restraints under Section 3(4) of the Act, causing an appreciable adverse effect on competition (AAEC).

Despite the violations, the CCI refrained from imposing monetary penalties due to remedial measures undertaken by the associations and the fact that it was a first-time offense. Instead, a cease-and-desist order was issued under Section 27, warning of stricter consequences for repeat offenses. The ruling reinforces athletes’ right to compete and signals a shift toward player-centric regulation, requiring federations to adapt to a more open sporting ecosystem. The ruling highlights the need for sports federations to align their practices with fair competition principles and replace restrictive policies with transparent governance frameworks. The verdict also supports market access, innovation, and athlete choice in the evolving landscape of Indian sports.

title: Arbitration Survives Termination: Telangana High Court Clarifies Scope In Urbanwoods Realty Real Estate Dispute
description:
The Telangana High Court has upheld the validity of arbitration agreements in a dispute between Urbanwoods Realty LLP and the respondents, reinforcing arbitration as a key method for resolving complex commercial issues. The case (Arbitration Application No. 41 of 2023) arose from a joint development MoU and subsequent agreement of sale concerning a 2-acre plot, where disputes emerged over payment obligations and project timelines.

Urbanwoods Realty sought the appointment of an arbitrator under the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996, while the respondents argued that termination of the MoU and agreement of sale nullified the arbitration clause. The court emphasized the doctrine of separability, affirming that an arbitration clause remains valid even if the main contract is terminated. The court's role under Section 11 is limited to verifying the existence of a prima facie arbitration agreement, without delving into the dispute's merits or contract validity.

The court interpreted the MoU and agreement of sale as a single transaction. Despite the use of "may" in the agreement of sale's arbitration clause, the court concluded that the intention to arbitrate was clear when considering both agreements together. Objections regarding insufficient stamping were deemed issues for the arbitral tribunal to decide. The High Court appointed Sri Justice V. V. S. Rao as the sole arbitrator, tasking the tribunal with resolving all issues, including the termination of the underlying agreements. This ruling underscores the importance of well-drafted arbitration clauses and the court's commitment to upholding arbitration as an efficient dispute resolution mechanism.

title: Redefining Parenthood: Historic Ruling on Transgender Rights in Kerala
description:
The Kerala High Court has delivered a landmark judgement affirming the rights of a transgender couple to be recognized as parents without adhering to binary gender roles. In *Zahhad & Anr. v. State of Kerala & Ors.*, Justice Ziyad Rahman directed the Kozhikode Corporation to issue a birth certificate identifying the couple simply as "parents," instead of "father" and "mother." This decision marks a significant step towards inclusive family law in India, offering hope for queer and transgender families.

The case arose after Zahhad, a transgender man, gave birth to a child with Ziya Paval, a transgender woman. Despite their legal recognition as transgender individuals, the child's initial birth certificate designated Zahhad as "mother" and Ziya as "father," contradicting their identities. The couple sought the court's intervention to be recognized as "parents" to avoid potential psychological, legal, and social consequences for their child.

Justice Rahman grounded his decision in Articles 14, 15, 19, and 21 of the Constitution, emphasizing equality, non-discrimination, freedom of expression, and the right to life and dignity. The court adopted a "social context adjudication" approach, asserting its constitutional responsibility to ensure equality when strict legal interpretations lead to injustice. The ruling signifies a monumental stride for the LGBTQIA+ community in India, as it acknowledges transgender parenthood and strengthens constitutional values of equality, dignity, and non-discrimination.

title: Safeguarding Brand Identity: Delhi High Court Declares ‘RITZ’ A Well-Known Trademark
description:
The Delhi High Court, in the case of *The Ritz Hotel Limited v. M S Hotel Ritz*, ruled in favor of The Ritz Hotel Limited, declaring the trademark "RITZ" a well-known trademark under Section 2(1)(zg) and Section 11(7) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The case involved the Plaintiff's claim of trademark infringement and passing off against the Defendants.

The Plaintiff, owner of "The Ritz Paris," argued that the Defendants' use of "RITZ" for hotel services was misleading customers and damaging their reputation. The Plaintiff emphasized the long-standing history, global recognition, and extensive promotion of the "RITZ" and "RITZ-CARLTON" marks. The Defendants initially agreed to cease using the marks but were later found to still be using them, leading to further legal action.

The court, noting the extensive use, geographical reach, public awareness, and goodwill associated with the Plaintiff's marks, determined that "RITZ" and "RITZ-CARLTON" had achieved the status of well-known trademarks. A permanent injunction was issued, preventing the Defendants from using the infringing marks and directing them to discontinue their websites. The uncontested nature of the proceedings highlighted that a trademark can be declared well-known even without significant opposition, provided the statutory criteria are satisfied. The ruling reinforces the importance of brand identity and safeguards names with established reputations from misuse.

title: NCDEX Discontinues Nest Portal: Investor Grievances To Be Addressed Via SEBI’s Smart ODR
description:
The National Commodity & Derivatives Exchange Limited (NCDEX) has discontinued its NEST (NCDEX Electronic System for Tracking grievances) portal, effective June 11, 2025, aligning with SEBI's centralized Online Dispute Resolution (ODR) mechanism. The NEST portal, introduced in January 2023, facilitated direct filing and tracking of investor grievances within the NCDEX ecosystem.

This transition is driven by SEBI's push for a unified grievance redressal system through its SMART ODR platform, as outlined in the SEBI Master Circular for Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations. The shift to SMART ODR aims to eliminate duplication of effort and ensure consistency in dispute resolution across the financial and commodity markets.

Investors and market participants are now required to lodge complaints through SEBI's SMART ODR platform or SCORES, as the NEST portal is no longer operational for new complaints. This change ensures investor access to a streamlined and efficient dispute resolution process.

The discontinuation of the NEST portal underscores NCDEX's commitment to regulatory compliance and its adoption of tech-driven solutions for effective grievance handling. Stakeholders are encouraged to update their compliance procedures and client support systems accordingly, utilizing the contact channels provided by NCDEX or their registered intermediaries for clarification.

title: Consumer Rights Vs. Corporate Responsibility: A Legal Perspective
description:
The District Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission, Mumbai Suburban, recently addressed a case, *Gargi Prakash Joshi & Another v. Wow Momos Foods Pvt. Ltd.*, concerning alleged deficiency in service under Section 35(1)(a) of the Consumer Protection Act, 2019. The complaint stemmed from the complainants being purportedly served non-vegetarian food (chicken momos) despite explicitly ordering a vegetarian "Steam Darjeeling Momo Combo" at a Wow Momos outlet.

The complainants argued that this alleged negligence caused significant emotional distress and violated their religious sentiments, leading them to seek Rs. 6,00,000 in compensation. Wow Momos countered by claiming the complainants ordered non-vegetarian food, as shown on the invoice, and highlighted the availability of clear labeling and a complaint mechanism which the complainants ignored. They further argued that the complainants did not qualify as "consumers" under the Act, asserting that a refund had been processed and thus no deficiency remained.

Ultimately, the Commission dismissed the complaint due to insufficient evidence proving the complainants ordered vegetarian momos or unknowingly consumed non-vegetarian food. The Commission also referenced that the labelling on the display board did provide some clarity and pointed to inconsistencies in the complainants' arguments.

title: IndiaLaw Monthly Newsletter – May Edition: Key Highlights
description:
This edition of the IndiaLaw Monthly Newsletter covers significant developments in corporate and commercial law, focusing on consumer protection, emerging commerce models, regulatory updates, and real estate liability.

A key case discussed involves a Consumer Forum's rejection of an insurer's narrow interpretation of "accident" in a rabies death claim. The newsletter also explores the legal complexities arising from the rapid growth of 10-minute commerce in India, specifically addressing challenges related to dark stores, quick commerce, and zonal compliance.

Furthermore, it highlights SEBI's recent directives aimed at redefining Know Your Customer (KYC) norms to ensure universal accessibility. Finally, the newsletter summarizes a Supreme Court ruling clarifying that developers are not liable for a homebuyer's loan interest incurred due to delays in flat possession.

title: IndiaMART vs. PUMA: Balancing IP Protection and Intermediary Liability in the Digital Age
description:
The Delhi High Court addressed the intersection of Intellectual Property Rights and intermediary liability in the case of *IndiaMART Intermesh Limited vs. PUMA SE*. The central issue was whether IndiaMART's use of the trademark "PUMA" as a brand keyword on its B2B marketplace constituted trademark infringement, given that the platform facilitated listings that potentially included counterfeit PUMA goods.

PUMA contended that IndiaMART facilitated the sale of counterfeit goods by allowing sellers to use the "PUMA" mark as a keyword, infringing on their registered trademark. IndiaMART argued that it operated as an intermediary under Section 2(1)(w) of the Information Technology Act, 2000, providing a platform for sellers without altering their content, and therefore should not be held liable for third-party listings.

The court overturned the Single Judge's order, stating that offering "PUMA" as a brand keyword did not inherently constitute trademark infringement under Section 29 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The court emphasized that IndiaMART provided listing services and was not directly involved in the sales transactions between buyers and sellers. Furthermore, the court affirmed IndiaMART's immunity as an intermediary under Section 79(1) of the IT Act, as it did not originate or modify the content and took down infringing listings upon notification.

The judgment reinforces the principles established in *Shreya Singhal v. Union of India*, clarifying that intermediaries are only deemed to have “actual knowledge” of unlawful content upon receiving a court order or formal notification from a government agency. Private complaints alone are insufficient to remove statutory immunity. This ruling establishes a balance between protecting trademark holders and preventing undue burdens on intermediaries, urging collaboration between platforms and IP owners through established grievance mechanisms. The decision highlights the need for robust monitoring and reporting systems to prevent counterfeit listings while preserving operational freedom and innovation within the digital economy.

title: Consumer Forum Rejects Insurer's Restrictive Interpretation of 'Accident' in Rabies Death Case
description:
The Uttarakhand State Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission ruled in favor of the complainant, Smt. Meera Srivastava, against IFFCO Tokio General Insurance Co. Ltd., reinforcing the principle that insurers must explicitly define exclusions in their policies. The case stemmed from the insurer's denial of a claim following the death of Smt. Srivastava’s husband due to complications from rabies, covered under a Personal Accident Insurance Policy.

IFFCO Tokio rejected the claim, arguing that the policy covered events like road accidents and burns, not infectious diseases. However, the Commission found no specific policy clause excluding rabies or viral infections. They reasoned that the policy's definition of "injury" as an accidental bodily injury caused by external, violent, and visible means could encompass a rabies infection resulting from an animal bite. This interpretation aligns with legal precedents, including a Supreme Court ruling that snakebites qualify as accidental deaths under such policies.

The Commission invoked the "contra proferentem" rule, stating that ambiguities in insurance contracts must be interpreted in favor of the policyholder. They concluded that IFFCO Tokio's repudiation lacked justification and constituted a deficiency in service under the Consumer Protection Act. The Commission directed IFFCO Tokio to pay the insured amount, compensation for mental anguish, and litigation costs. This decision underscores the importance of clear policy language and fair claim handling by insurers, particularly in cases of personal loss, and highlights that consumer forums will intervene when policyholder expectations are not met.

title: Redefining KYC: SEBI’s Directives for Universal Accessibility
description:
The increasing digitization of services in India, propelled by initiatives like the Digital India Programme, necessitates inclusive digital processes, particularly in Know Your Customer (KYC) procedures. The Supreme Court of India's judgment in *Pragya Prasun v. Union of India* broadens Article 21 to ensure digital accessibility for all, including persons with disabilities (PwDs), aligning with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD) and the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016 (RPwD Act).

The legal framework emphasizes equal rights for PwDs in managing their financial affairs (Section 13(1) of the RPwD Act) and mandates access to information and communication technologies (ICT) through audio descriptions and sign language (Section 42). Section 46 requires service providers to achieve accessibility compliance, supported by the National Policy on Universal Electronic Accessibility, 2013.

Enforcement mechanisms, including nodal officers, accessibility audits involving visually impaired individuals, and alternative liveness verification methods from the RBI, are crucial. Inclusive communication options like sign language and accessible formats such as Braille are essential. The Government of Goa has implemented inclusive practices like alternative verification methods and guardian assistance.

SEBI's circular on May 23, 2025, directs registered intermediaries to adopt alternative KYC verification methods such as head movements, OTP-based authentication, and real-time video recordings, in alignment with the Supreme Court’s directives and the RPwD Act. This initiative recognizes digital access as a fundamental right under Article 21 and emphasizes the responsibility of service providers to adopt universal design principles. The Supreme Court's judgment in *Pragya Prasun v. Union of India* underscores the need for inclusive digital services and sets a strong example for integrating accessibility into India's digital infrastructure.

title: New CERSAI Compliance: Source of Funds Mandatory for SI Filings
description:
The Central Registry of Securitisation Asset Reconstruction and Security Interest of India (CERSAI) has introduced a new compliance requirement mandating financial institutions to disclose the source of funds when registering a security interest. This initiative aims to enhance regulatory oversight and improve transparency, particularly in on-lending or refinance arrangements.

Established under the SARFAESI Act, CERSAI maintains a central registry of charges on movable, immovable, and intangible assets. The new mandatory fields introduced by CERSAI include the type of lending (direct lending, on-lending, or refinance), the Entity ID of the original lending institution (e.g., NABARD, NHB, SIDBI) in on-lending or refinance scenarios, and the Security Interest ID of the corresponding registration where refinance or on-lending is secured by a prior charge.

This development has significant implications for banks, NBFCs, housing finance companies, and other lending institutions, requiring them to adapt their processes to capture and report the source of funds accurately. Proactive preparation will be essential for institutions to reduce compliance risk and ensure the continued legal enforceability of their secured interests. The objective is to bring greater clarity and control over lending chains and fund flows, particularly in multi-layered credit structures.

title: Madras High Court Affirms Same-Sex Couples Can Constitute a Family, Even Without Marriage
description:
The Madras High Court, in the case of MA v Superintendent of Police, has reaffirmed that same-sex couples can constitute a family, even in the absence of formal marriage. This ruling emerged from a habeas corpus petition filed under Article 226 of the Constitution, addressing the alleged unlawful detention and coercion of a woman by her family due to her sexual orientation. The court's decision emphasizes personal liberty, autonomy, and an evolving understanding of family, reflecting a progressive stance on LGBTQIA+ rights within the existing legal framework.

The case was initiated by a petitioner seeking the release of her partner, who was allegedly being held against her will and subjected to coercive measures aimed at altering her sexual orientation. This was considered within the context of evolving LGBTQIA+ jurisprudence, particularly landmark judgments like NALSA v. Union of India and Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India, which decriminalized consensual same-sex relationships.

Justices G.R. Swaminathan and Justice V. Lakshminarayan ruled in favor of the petitioner, asserting the detainee's right to make her own life choices. The court reiterated that the concept of family extends beyond traditional definitions to include chosen families, underscoring personal autonomy as a cornerstone of dignity and freedom. The judiciary's role in safeguarding the constitutional rights of marginalized communities, including LGBTQIA+ individuals, was also emphasized.

The court also cited Article 21 of the Indian Constitution, guaranteeing the right to life and personal liberty, and referenced the Yogyakarta Principles advocating for the universal enjoyment of human rights, including the right to form families free from discrimination based on sexual orientation. The court allowed the detainee to leave with the petitioner and ordered the police to ensure the couple's safety and address complaints from the LGBTQIA+ community promptly. This decision marks a significant step in recognizing and protecting the rights of LGBTQIA+ individuals in India, emphasizing the importance of judicial intervention in the absence of legislative recognition for same-sex marriage.

title: Revisiting FIR Quashing: Supreme Court’s Perspective in Abhishek Singh V. Ajay Kumar & ORS
description:
The Supreme Court of India, in *Abhishek Singh v. Ajay Kumar & Ors*, addressed the principles governing the quashing of FIRs, emphasizing the importance of prima facie evidence and procedural fairness. The case stemmed from allegations of fraud and misappropriation related to a loan agreement where the appellant, Abhishek Singh, pledged gold ornaments as collateral, which were later deemed counterfeit by the bank without his knowledge.

The Patna High Court had quashed Singh's FIR, viewing it as a retaliatory measure lacking prima facie evidence. It further stated the appellant failed to file an affidavit under Section 156(3) CrPC. However, the Supreme Court overturned the High Court's decision, asserting that the quashing of an FIR should be based on the presence of a prima facie case, not an in-depth analysis of evidence at the preliminary stage.

The Supreme Court found that the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction by engaging in evidentiary appreciation, a role reserved for the trial court. It noted inconsistencies in the High Court's reasoning, particularly concerning the appellant's intent and the absence of third-party verification during the gold revaluation. The Supreme Court restored the FIR, directing the trial court to proceed with the matter according to the law, and emphasized that its decision was not a reflection of the merit of the allegations. This decision underscores the caution required when quashing an FIR, ensuring thorough examination of allegations presenting a prima facie case through due process.

title: Supreme Court Rules: Developer Not Liable for Homebuyer’s Loan Interest Due to Delay in Flat Possession
description:
On June 4, 2025, the Supreme Court of India delivered a judgment in a case involving the Greater Mohali Area Development Authority (GMADA) and homebuyers Anupam Garg and Rajiv Kumar. The case centered on delays and unilateral changes in the 'Purab Premium Apartments' housing project, initiated in 2011. The court examined the legal obligations of developers and the rights of consumers under Indian law.

The dispute arose after delays in the project's completion beyond the initial possession date of May 21, 2015. Anupam Garg, an allottee, filed a consumer complaint citing a lack of progress and unilateral changes. The State Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (SCDRC) and the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (NCDRC) initially ruled in favor of Garg, directing GMADA to refund the deposited amount with interest, compensation, and the interest paid on Garg's loan.

GMADA appealed to the Supreme Court, contesting its liability for the loan interest. The Supreme Court, referencing precedents like *Bangalore Development Authority v. Syndicate Bank* and *GDA v. Balbir Singh*, ruled that GMADA was not liable for the homebuyers' loan interest. The Court deemed the already awarded 8% interest sufficient compensation for the delay, emphasizing that compensation must be based on specific losses or injuries suffered by the consumer.

The Supreme Court's decision clarifies the extent of a developer's liability in cases of project delays, setting a precedent for future disputes. It reinforces the need for developers to adhere to contractual obligations and provide reasonable compensation for delays, while preventing undue financial burdens. The judgment aims to promote transparency, accountability, and fairness in the housing market, reaffirming the Court's commitment to protecting the interests of all parties involved in consumer disputes.

title: From Shelf to Scooter: The Legal Mess Behind India’s 10-Minute Commerce Boom
description:
India's burgeoning quick commerce sector, characterized by companies promising deliveries in 10 minutes or less, faces substantial legal and regulatory hurdles. These challenges range from zoning violations due to strategically located "dark stores" in residential areas to food safety concerns and questions surrounding the rights and classifications of gig workers as "independent contractors". The article also considers the impacts on cost per order, profitability, and service fees on consumer interests.

Regulatory compliance remains a major concern. Quick commerce platforms, often classified as IT companies, navigate grey areas to sidestep stringent retail regulations and labor laws which enable them to engage in predatory pricing practices. This has prompted investigations from the Competition Commission of India (CCI).

The sector also grapples with economic sustainability. High operational costs and initially low average order values (AOV) present profitability challenges. While some platforms have managed to increase their AOV, this often involves offering higher-value product categories, each bringing its own regulatory and compliance complexities. Service fees and packaging costs further impact consumer interest and raise concerns from consumer protection agencies.

Consumer protection is another critical area of focus. The Central Consumer Protection Authority (CCPA) scrutinizes delivery time claims and addresses issues like differential pricing based on device type. The CCPA is also cracking down on "dark patterns" through self-audits required of e-commerce platforms, designed to promote ethical and transparent user interfaces.

Furthermore, the gig worker model employed by many quick commerce platforms has been under the scanner. Concerns arise regarding fair working conditions, lack of social security benefits, and pressures leading to unsafe practices. States like Rajasthan and Karnataka are introducing ordinances and acts to protect gig workers' rights and ensure welfare.

Food safety is also a major area of regulatory focus. The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) has issued comprehensive guidelines and licensing requirements for e-commerce food businesses, addressing concerns over hygiene and standards. Compliance is critical, with penalties for violations.

Moreover, compliance with Legal Metrology (Packaged Commodity) Rules, 2011, is crucial to prevent misleading practices in quantity declaration and product labeling. Similarly, data privacy concerns arise from the vast amounts of consumer data collected by these platforms, with the Personal Data Protection Act, 2023, aiming to regulate data collection, usage, and storage.

Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in retail e-commerce in India is allowed up to 100% under the automatic route for marketplaces, while inventory-based e-commerce is not permitted, balancing the need for foreign capital with the protection of domestic businesses. Lastly, ensuring quality standards through hallmarking and adherence to BIS (Bureau of Indian Standards) is essential for products like jewelry and electronics to protect consumers from substandard goods.

title: Bombay High Court Grants Full Reimbursement for Heart Surgery, Prioritizing Right to Life
description:
In a significant ruling, the Bombay High Court in *Anirudh Prataprai Nansi v. Union of India* directed the Central Government to fully reimburse ₹22,08,440 to Mr. Nansi, a retired government employee, for a heart transplant conducted at a private hospital. The court emphasized the primacy of Article 21 of the Constitution, safeguarding the right to life, in cases where essential medical treatment is unavailable through government-sponsored channels.

The case arose from Mr. Nansi's urgent need for a heart transplant due to severe cardiomyopathy. Because no Central Government Health Scheme (CGHS)-approved hospital in Mumbai was equipped to perform the procedure at the time, he underwent the transplant at a private facility. The CGHS authorities initially approved a reimbursement based on an outdated CGHS-Mumbai rate of ₹69,000, which was significantly lower than the actual expenses.

The High Court strongly criticized the CGHS's narrow, technical approach, asserting that rigid procedural compliance should give way to compassion and constitutional values in life-saving situations. The court highlighted that heart transplants are inherently urgent, the right to health is integral to Article 21, and the government has the power to relax guidelines in medical emergencies. It also emphasized that the lack of empanelled facilities cannot justify denying essential care and questioned the outdated and discriminatory reimbursement rates. The judgment reinforces that public health policies must prioritize the well-being and constitutional rights of individuals, especially in critical medical situations.

title: Bombay High Court Allows Accused to Travel Abroad Amid Matrimonial Dispute
description:
The Bombay High Court granted permission to a Non-resident Indian (NRI) employed in the United States to travel abroad for work, despite facing charges in a matrimonial case. The ruling in *Sukrutkumar Babasaheb Bhandare vs. State of Maharashtra & Anr.* demonstrates a balanced judicial approach, considering both the accused's livelihood and the integrity of legal proceedings.

The petitioner, Sukrutkumar Babasaheb Bhandare, was charged under various sections of the Indian Penal Code based on a complaint filed by his wife. He sought permission to return to the US, where he is employed. The Sessions Court initially rejected his plea, citing potential disruption to the investigation and mediation. Subsequently, the petitioner filed a Writ Petition.

The High Court considered arguments from both parties, including the husband's cooperation with authorities and the wife's concern regarding withheld documents. Through joint request and exploration, both parties agreed to certain conditions. The conditions are that the husband hand over all documents and certificates belonging to the wife, provide electronic data stored on his laptop,andundertaking to participate and cooperate in the trial without causing any obstruction or delay.

Justice Ashwin D. Bhobe, appreciating the cooperative approach, set aside the previous order and allowed the husband to travel, contingent upon adherence to the agreed-upon conditions. This case underscores the value of flexibility and cooperation in legal processes, showcasing how a balanced approach can lead to a just resolution that respects the rights and needs of all parties involved.

title: Section 95 IBC: NCLAT Chennai Bars Consecutive Insolvency Applications Against Same Guarantor
description:
The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) in Chennai recently addressed the issue of consecutive insolvency resolution proceedings against a personal guarantor under Section 95 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (I&B Code) in the case of "Indian Bank v. K R Tirumuruhan." This case clarifies the legal constraints when multiple financial creditors attempt to initiate insolvency proceedings against the same guarantor.

The NCLAT upheld the NCLT's decision to dismiss Indian Bank's application, citing Section 96 of the I&B Code, which bars subsequent applications once proceedings have been initiated by another financial creditor. The ruling referenced a similar prior judgment, Indian Bank, SAMB, Chennai Vs T. Prabhakar, reinforcing the principle that the initial application takes precedence.

The final decision dismissed the appeal, emphasizing the importance of adhering to the I&B Code and legal precedents. The NCLAT also directed the NCLT to expedite the pending Section 95 proceedings that prompted the appeal. This judgment reinforces the need for financial creditors to be aware of existing proceedings before initiating new ones to ensure the efficient and fair resolution of insolvency cases.

title: Industrial Disputes Act and Article 19(1)(g): Supreme Court Upholds Right to Close Business
description:
The Supreme Court of India, in *Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. (Biscuit Division) versus the State of Maharashtra*, addressed the legality of industrial closures under the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, and the constitutional right to close a business per Article 19(1)(g). The case stemmed from Harinagar Sugar Mills Limited's (HSML) closure of its biscuit division following the termination of a long-standing job work agreement with Britannia Industries Limited (BIL).

HSML applied for closure, but the Government of Maharashtra requested additional information, which HSML provided. When the authorities requested resubmission, HSML argued that closure permission was automatically granted per Section 25-O(3) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, due to the government's failure to respond within 60 days. The Bombay High Court dismissed HSML's petitions, deeming the application incomplete.

The Supreme Court overturned the High Court's decision, holding that the initial request for information was not an order and the Deputy Secretary lacked the authority to request resubmission. The Court emphasized that the right to close a business is intrinsic to the right to conduct business under Article 19(1)(g), albeit subject to reasonable restrictions in the public interest under Article 19(6). The Court ruled that the 60-day period for deemed closure should be calculated from the initial application date, implying closure approval. HSML was directed to pay an additional Rs. 15 crores as compensation to the affected employees.

title: RBI's Lending Against Gold and Silver Collateral Directions, 2025
description:
On June 6, 2025, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) released the Reserve Bank of India (Lending Against Gold and Silver Collateral) Directions, 2025, a unified regulatory framework designed to harmonize the treatment of loans secured by gold and silver across all regulated entities (REs). The reform aims to enhance prudence, borrower protection, and operational transparency within the gold loan sector.

The new Directions consolidate and repeal over 30 circulars issued between 1964 and 2023, addressing inconsistencies and supervisory gaps arising from the previously fragmented regulatory structure. Applicable to a wide range of REs, the Directions will be fully effective by April 1, 2026, with loans sanctioned prior to this date remaining subject to the guidelines in effect at the time of issuance.

Key provisions include restricting permissible collateral to gold and silver jewellery, ornaments, and coins, while prohibiting lending against primary gold/silver bullion or financial instruments backed by such assets. Loan-to-Value (LTV) caps have been introduced and must be maintained throughout the loan tenure, alongside standardized assaying and valuation procedures. Consumer protection measures, operational restrictions, AML checks, guidelines for top-up loans and renewals, collateral management, auction transparency, and provisions for unclaimed collateral are also outlined. Furthermore, lenders are required to disclose detailed loan portfolio information relating to gold and silver-backed loans in their financial statements.

The RBI's 2025 Directions represent a forward-looking regulatory stance, unifying legacy norms into a single set of principles to promote responsible and transparent gold loan practices. Financial institutions are encouraged to view these guidelines as an opportunity to build trust and better serve customers, particularly those who rely on gold loans for short-term liquidity.

title: Authorized Officials Can Testify: J&K High Court Eases Cheque Bounce Procedure
description:
The Jammu & Kashmir High Court, in *Iftikhar Ashraf Trumboo v. Furqan Ahmad Rather*, has streamlined procedures for cheque dishonor cases under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881. The Court ruled that the personal appearance of a Branch Manager is not mandatory for proving bank records. Any duly authorized bank official with access to the necessary records is competent to testify, thereby overturning a Trial Magistrate's overly strict procedural interpretation.

The case originated from a Section 138 complaint where a cheque was dishonored due to insufficient funds. When the complainant presented an authorized bank representative in lieu of the Branch Manager, the Trial Magistrate refused to record their testimony, demanding a formal substitution application. The High Court found this insistence on procedural formalities to be excessive and legally incorrect.

Justice Sanjay Dhar clarified that any responsible bank officer with access to account records in the ordinary course of business can testify to documentary evidence, such as cheque return memos, without needing personal knowledge. The Court also deemed the invocation of Section 302 of the Criminal Procedure Code unnecessary, as it obstructs the summary nature of Section 138 proceedings. The admissibility of such evidence is governed by Sections 65B and 67 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872, which facilitate the admission of electronic and documentary records maintained in the ordinary course of business.

This decision aligns with existing legal principles promoting swift justice in cheque dishonor cases, as emphasized by the Supreme Court in *Indian Bank Association v. Union of India (2014)*. The J&K High Court's ruling reinforces the importance of efficient resolution of cheque bounce disputes, preventing procedural technicalities from hindering prompt justice under Section 138 of the NI Act.

title: CCPA Mandates Self-Audit for E-Commerce Platforms to Eliminate Dark Patterns
description:
The Central Consumer Protection Authority (CCPA) issued an advisory on June 5, 2025, mandating all e-commerce platforms in India to conduct self-audits to identify and eliminate dark patterns within three months. This directive, issued under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019, aims to foster a transparent and ethical digital ecosystem that prioritizes consumer interests.

This action builds upon the "Guidelines for Prevention and Regulation of Dark Patterns, 2023," by introducing a proactive compliance mechanism. Dark patterns are defined as manipulative design elements used to deceive users into unintended actions, such as unwanted purchases or unknowingly sharing personal data. The CCPA aims to ensure consumers are not subjected to coercive or misleading digital experiences.

The Department of Consumer Affairs has already issued notices to 11 e-commerce platforms for violating the 2023 guidelines, demonstrating the seriousness of non-compliance. Platforms must prioritize adhering to CCPA principles, including design teams, legal and compliance departments, and marketing. Non-compliance could result in regulatory scrutiny, penalties, and reputational damage.

This advisory signifies a crucial step towards a safer and more equitable digital economy in India, compelling e-commerce platforms to prioritize consumer welfare over manipulative growth tactics, emphasizing proactive compliance and responsible governance.

title: Mandatory Induction of CNG or Electric Vehicles by Aggregators and E-Commerce Entities in Delhi NCR
description:
The Commission for Air Quality Management (CAQM) has issued a directive mandating that all new fleet additions by motor vehicle aggregators, delivery service providers, and e-commerce platforms in Delhi-NCR must exclusively consist of compressed natural gas (CNG) or electric vehicles (EVs). This policy intervention aims to significantly reduce vehicular emissions in the highly polluted National Capital Region.

The CAQM invoked its authority under the Commission for Air Quality Management in National Capital Region and Adjoining Areas Act, 2021, issuing Direction No. 94 dated 03.06.2025. This directive applies to entities operating fleets of 25 or more vehicles and requires a phased transition to CNG and EV fleets.

Vehicular pollution, especially from commercial vehicles, significantly contributes to air pollution in the NCR. The rapid growth of e-commerce and app-based logistics has exacerbated this issue. This policy aligns with national initiatives like the National Electric Mobility Mission Plan (NEMMP), the Faster Adoption and Manufacturing of Hybrid and Electric Vehicles (FAME) schemes, and state EV policies, promoting a cleaner transport ecosystem. The CAQM directive represents a key regulatory effort to decarbonize commercial transportation in the NCR and achieve sustainable logistics with legal backing.

title: Delhi High Court Upholds Maintenance Obligations Under Section 24 Of The Hindu Marriage Act
description:
The Delhi High Court, in *Subhash v. Mamta @ Raksha*, reaffirmed that a husband's obligation to maintain his wife and child under Section 24 of the Hindu Marriage Act (HMA), which provides for interim maintenance during matrimonial proceedings, cannot be diminished by citing personal financial commitments like loan EMIs or insurance premiums. The court emphasized that maintenance calculations should be based on the husband's earning capacity and gross income, excluding voluntary expenses, thus safeguarding dependent spouses and children from attempts to evade maintenance responsibilities.

The case arose from a marital dispute where the wife sought interim maintenance after the husband filed for divorce. The Family Court ordered the husband, with a declared monthly income of ₹47,000, to pay ₹15,000 monthly for the wife and child. The husband challenged this, arguing reduced disposable income due to loan obligations and insurance payments. The High Court rejected these arguments, stating that voluntary financial obligations cannot supersede the primary duty to maintain dependents.

The Court's analysis aligned with the Supreme Court’s stance in *Manish Jain v. Akanksha Jain*, emphasizing that financial commitments like home loans cannot dilute the legal duty of maintenance. The court also found the wife's unemployment to be genuine due to caregiving responsibilities, consistent with *Shailja & Anr. v. Khobbanna*, which affirms a qualified wife's entitlement to maintenance if she's not earning due to legitimate duties. The ruling reinforces the judiciary's commitment to protecting the financial well-being of spouses and children post-separation. Voluntary personal expenses cannot reduce statutory maintenance. The judgement makes maintenance an effective financial safeguard.

title: Safeguarding Consumer Communication: Addressing Unsolicited Commercial Communication
description:
Unsolicited Commercial Communication (UCC), or spam, poses significant challenges in the digital age, including privacy violations and cybersecurity risks. These unrequested messages, promoting goods or services, necessitate robust regulations and technological solutions to protect consumers. The Telecom Commercial Communications Customer Preference Regulations (TCCCPR), 2018, and its subsequent amendments, aim to tackle UCC through enhanced measures.

The TCCCPR defines UCC as any commercial communication that doesn't align with the recipient's consent, excluding transactional and government-issued messages. The Second Amendment, introduced in 2025, refines the framework by classifying mixed promotional content as promotional, requiring prior notification for auto-diallers, and implementing stricter provider obligations such as communication authentication and adherence to regulations. A key update is the abolishment of inferred consent from existing business relationships, mandating fresh consent after service contract termination.

A streamlined complaint mechanism, featuring a standardised format and quicker response times, is now in place to bolster consumer control. Consumers can report UCC with minimal information, and service providers must respond within five days. Violators face penalties ranging from fines to blacklisting and service disconnection. Technical measures, consumer education campaigns, and proactive registration with "do-not-disturb" services further aid in combating spam.

Globally, countries are employing various strategies, with India's blockchain-based Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT) framework setting a high standard by ensuring transparency, accountability, and explicit consent. This contrasts with the US CAN-SPAM Act's opt-out mechanisms and the EU GDPR's focus on explicit consent. Effective UCC mitigation requires collaborative efforts among regulators, telecom providers, and consumers, along with ongoing innovation and the adoption of best practices to foster trust and integrity in digital communication.

title: Kerala High Court Upholds Right to Religious Identity in Educational Records: Sudhin Krishna Case
description:
The Kerala High Court, in the case of *Sudhin Krishna C. S. v State of Kerala and Ors*, reaffirmed an individual's constitutional right under Article 25 to freely choose and reflect their religious identity in official records. The ruling, delivered by Justice D.K. Singh, centered on a petitioner's request to amend his name and religion in his educational documents.

Sudhin Krishna C.S., originally registered as Mohammed Riyazudeen C.S., sought to correct his records to reflect his Hindu identity, which he adopted upon reaching adulthood. The District Educational Officer (DEO) denied his request, citing the Kerala Education Rules (KER), 1959, as not explicitly allowing such changes. The petitioner then appealed to the Kerala High Court, arguing that Rule 3(1) of Chapter VI of the KER permitted such amendments.

The petitioner contended that Rule 3(1) of Chapter VI of the KER explicitly allows changes to details such as name, religion, and caste, citing the violation of religious freedom under Article 25 of the Constitution. The respondents countered that the KER primarily addressed corrections to dates of birth, limiting the Commissioner of Examinations' authority to make broader changes.

The High Court interpreted Rule 3(1) of Chapter VI of the KER to encompass alterations beyond just the date of birth, extending to personal details like name, religion, and caste. The court directed the respondents to amend the petitioner's educational records to accurately reflect his chosen name and religion, underscoring the principles of personal liberty, self-determination, and the right to an accurate representation of one’s chosen identity in official documents.

title: Karnataka's 2025 Tobacco Law Overhaul: Implications for Businesses and Citizens
description:
On May 30, 2025, the Government of Karnataka enacted the Cigarettes and Other Tobacco Products (Prohibition of Advertisement and Regulation of Trade and Commerce, Production, Supply, and Distribution) (Karnataka Amendment) Act, 2024, amending the COTPA, 2003. Key changes include raising the legal age for purchasing tobacco products from 18 to 21 years and increasing the maximum fine for violations from ₹200 to ₹1,000. The legislation aims to strengthen tobacco control and reduce consumption, particularly among youth.

The amendment broadens the prohibition of tobacco use in public places to include both smoking and spitting, while allowing designated smoking areas in larger hotels, restaurants, and airports that meet specific requirements. A complete ban on hookah bars has also been introduced, reflecting the state's effort to regulate tobacco consumption in social environments. The sale of tobacco products is now restricted to individuals 21 years and older, and increased scrutiny will be applied to sales near educational institutions.

Significant penalties have been introduced for operating hookah bars, including imprisonment from one to three years and fines ranging from ₹50,000 to ₹1,00,000. Dr. U.S. Vishal Rao, a member of Karnataka’s High-Powered Committee on Tobacco Control, believes these amendments are a crucial step in curbing tobacco use among the younger population. Bengaluru Police Commissioner B. Dayananda has emphasized strict enforcement, urging establishments to adhere to COTPA guidelines for designated smoking areas.

title: Supreme Court Reaffirms Finality in AGR Dues: Dismisses Vodafone Idea’s Writ Petitions
description:
The Supreme Court of India dismissed writ petitions filed by Vodafone Idea Ltd. and other telecom operators, reaffirming the finality of its previous rulings on Adjusted Gross Revenue (AGR) dues. The petitions, filed under Article 32 of the Constitution, challenged the imposition of interest, penalties, and interest on penalties related to AGR.

The core issue stems from differing interpretations of AGR between telecom operators and the Department of Telecommunications (DoT). A 2019 Supreme Court judgment sided with the DoT, significantly increasing the financial liabilities of telecom companies. While the Court allowed payment in ten annual installments in 2020, the operators sought further relief in 2025, arguing that interest and penalties were economically unsustainable.

The Supreme Court bench dismissed the petitions, emphasizing that Article 32 cannot be used to reopen conclusively decided matters. The Court underscored the importance of judicial discipline and the finality of its judgments, signaling that the remedy for economic grievances lies in policy engagement, not repeated litigation. This decision reinforces legal certainty for the telecom sector, urging companies to focus on operational stability and financial restructuring within the established framework of AGR liabilities and payment timelines.

title: Stamp Duty Compliance Just Got Smarter: Rajasthan Launches Mandatory API-Based Calculator For All Digital Document Executions
description:
The Government of Rajasthan has launched a mandatory automated Stamp Duty Calculator API for all digitally executed documents within the state's Digital Document Execution (DDE) platform, effective May 30, 2025. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Stock Holding Corporation of India Limited (SHCIL) and National E-Governance Services Ltd. (NeSL), aims to standardize stamp duty assessment and eliminate errors associated with manual calculations.

This new system enhances the DDE workflow by ensuring uniformity and accuracy in stamp duty calculation for transactions executed in Rajasthan, and it is intended to ensure accuracy by removing the possibility of manual entry errors.

The introduction of the Rajasthan Stamp Duty Calculator API represents a significant advancement in e-governance for digital legal documentation. By enforcing standardized, automated duty computation, the initiative strengthens regulatory compliance, reduces human error, and enhances operational efficiency for financial institutions. Stakeholders are advised to adapt quickly to ensure full compliance.

title: Calcutta High Court Upholds Scientific Merit Over Moral Speculation in Patent Law
description:
The Calcutta High Court recently ruled in favor of ITC Limited regarding their patent application for a "Heater Assembly to Generate Aerosol," overturning the Controller of Patents' initial rejection. The Controller had cited Section 3(b) of the Patents Act, 1970, expressing concerns about public health and morality related to the device's potential use, particularly given the Prohibition of Electronic Cigarettes Act, 2019.

The Court emphasized that patent denials based solely on moral or public health grounds require independent scientific or technical evidence, and subjective notions are insufficient justification. The Controller's assumption that the invention was exclusively intended for tobacco products was incorrect, as the device could be used with various substrates.

Justice Ravi Krishnan Kapur clarified that the e-cigarette ban addresses commercial activities, not the inherent patentability of an invention. Furthermore, the Controller's reliance on undisclosed documents violated principles of natural justice, denying ITC an opportunity to respond and rendering the decision procedurally flawed. The court has reaffirmed that bans on sale or distribution of products do not automatically equate to a ban on innovation and that health regulations should not unduly influence patent decisions.

In conclusion, the High Court set aside the Controller's order and remanded the matter for a fresh decision, stressing the need for a hearing and adherence to scientific and technical grounds. This ruling underscores the importance of relying on evidence-based assessments in patent law and establishes a narrower interpretation of Section 3(b), reinforcing the separation between health regulations and patent eligibility.

title: Breaking the Mold: Can Courts Now Rewrite Arbitral Awards?
description:
In *Gayatri Balasamy v. ISG Novasoft Technologies Ltd.*, a Supreme Court Constitution Bench addressed the power of Indian courts to modify arbitral awards under Sections 34 and 37 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996. The 4:1 majority held that limited judicial modification is permissible in specific circumstances, including clerical errors, severable portions, post-award interest, and under Article 142. This departs from the earlier decision in *NHAI v. Hakeem*, raising concerns about judicial overreach and its impact on the finality and autonomy of arbitration.

The case arose from conflicting judicial opinions regarding the power of Indian courts to modify arbitral awards, with some allowing it and others ruling against it. The Supreme Court aimed to resolve whether courts can modify awards or only set them aside. The Arbitration Act, modeled on the UNCITRAL Model Law, emphasizes limited court intervention, primarily allowing courts to set aside awards on specific grounds. However, the *Balasamy* ruling permits modifications in limited cases, sparking debate.

Supporters argue that limited judicial modifications promote judicial economy and prevent delays. Opponents maintain that such powers conflict with the legislative intent of the Arbitration Act, potentially undermining arbitration's core principles and inviting further litigation. The ruling endorses judicial modifications under narrow circumstances and constitutional powers under Article 142. This interpretation has raised concerns about the integrity and indivisibility of arbitral awards, as well as potentially breaching the separation of powers.

The majority's expansive view of Section 34 risks tactical litigation, weakens tribunal authority, and erodes arbitration’s finality. Arbitral awards are generally unified instruments, and selectively modifying them compromises their coherence. Justice K.V. Viswanathan's dissent underscores that Article 142 cannot override clear statutory provisions, stressing judicial restraint and respect for legislative boundaries. Ultimately, the *Balasamy* decision introduces a nuanced approach, allowing limited court modifications, including severing invalid portions, correcting errors, modifying post-award interest, and invoking Article 142 to ensure complete justice.

title: Supreme Court Rules on Retirement Age for Disabled Employees: A Summary of *Kashmiri Lal Sharma v. Himachal Pradesh State Electricity Board*
description:
The Supreme Court of India, in the case of *Kashmiri Lal Sharma v. Himachal Pradesh State Electricity Board*, addressed the issue of retirement age disparities among employees with disabilities. The appellant, a 60% locomotor-disabled electrician, challenged his retirement at age 58, arguing it violated Article 14 of the Constitution due to an earlier Office Memorandum (OM) that allowed visually impaired employees to work until 60. The State later withdrew this OM, reverting the retirement age to 58 for all categories.

The Court reaffirmed that setting the retirement age is a policy decision within the executive's purview, subject to the principles of equality. The appellant contended that the disparity violated Article 14 and that he had a legitimate expectation to work until 60 due to the OM's earlier existence. Conversely, the State argued that the OM's withdrawal negated any claims for extended retirement.

Referencing the Persons with Disabilities (PWD) Act, 1995, and the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (RPWD) Act, 2016, the Court emphasized the need for equal treatment regarding employment benefits for individuals with benchmark disabilities. While partially allowing the appeal, the Court ruled that the appellant was entitled to full wages and benefits until the OM's withdrawal date (November 4, 2019) and that his pension should be calculated accordingly. The Court firmly stated that employees do not have a vested right to continue employment beyond the date of the OM's withdrawal, reinforcing the executive's right to determine retirement age through policy decisions, while still adhering to constitutional principles of fairness and equality.

title: Admission of CIRP Under Section 7 of the IBC, 2016, is Liable to Be Recalled Upon Establishment of Fraud or Malicious Intent Under Section 65 of the Code
description:
The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) upheld the Adjudicating Authority's decision to terminate the Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP) against a corporate debtor, based on findings that the insolvency proceedings were initiated fraudulently and with malicious intent. This ruling underscores the importance of Section 65 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC), 2016, which safeguards against the abuse of the Code's process.

The case involved a dispute where the Appellants initiated CIRP under Section 7, claiming to be financial creditors. The Respondent argued that the CIRP was a fraudulent attempt to defeat ongoing litigation related to the illegal dilution of their shareholding. The Adjudicating Authority terminated the CIRP, citing collusion, document fabrication, and misuse of the insolvency process.

The NCLAT affirmed the NCLT’s findings, emphasizing that the existence of debt and default does not shield a Section 7 application from scrutiny under Section 65 when collusion or abuse is proven. The Tribunal found significant documentary inconsistencies, violations of corporate law, manipulation of timing, and corroborative evidence of fraud. The Court clarified that terminating the CIRP was an adjudication on fraud and not a review of the admission order.

This decision reinforces the judiciary's commitment to preventing the strategic abuse of the IBC, 2016. While Section 7 allows creditors to initiate CIRP based on financial debt and default, this mechanism is subject to scrutiny. Section 65 empowers the Adjudicating Authority to annul proceedings tainted by fraud or bad faith, thereby protecting the integrity of the Code.

title: Government Cracks Down On E-Commerce Dark Patterns
description:
The Indian government, through the Ministry of Consumer Affairs, has initiated enforcement action against eleven leading e-commerce and technology platforms for violating the "Guidelines for Prevention and Regulation of Dark Patterns, 2023." Notices were issued on May 28, 2025, citing deceptive user interface practices that mislead consumers.

These guidelines, effective since November 30, 2023, define dark patterns as manipulative design techniques that exploit cognitive biases to influence consumers into unintended actions, such as unwanted purchases or data sharing. Common examples include drip pricing, basket sneaking, and subscription traps, prevalent across various digital platforms.

The 2023 guidelines, legally binding under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019, identify thirteen specific types of dark patterns and encourage consumers to report violations. Despite this, several companies persisted in using these practices, prompting the government's action, which centered around deceptive advertising, forced actions, and subscription traps.

This enforcement aims to enhance transparency and fairness in online transactions, ensuring consumer consent and control. Businesses must now prioritize ethical design and compliance, facing potential penalties for non-compliance. This initiative marks a significant stride towards ethical digital engagement, safeguarding consumer rights and fostering responsible innovation in the digital economy.

title: PESO Introduces Online Module for Licensing Compressed Hydrogen Dispensing Stations in India
description:
The Petroleum and Explosives Safety Organisation (PESO), under the Government of India, launched an online module on May 14, 2025, to streamline the application process for licenses for Compressed Hydrogen Dispensing Stations under the Gas Cylinder Rules 2016.
